title: 109_s2205
content: The Act is titled the "Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2006". It pertains to the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal. The Blunt Reservoir feature and Pierre Canal feature are defined in the Act as part of the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program. The Commission refers to the Commission of Schools and Public Lands of the State. Nonpreferential lease parcels are land parcels purchased by the Secretary for use with the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features. The Pierre Canal feature is part of the Oahe Unit, James Division, authorized under the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program. A preferential leaseholder is someone who held a lease on a preferential lease parcel as of January 1, 2001. A preferential lease parcel is land purchased by the Secretary for use with the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features. The Secretary, defined as the Secretary of the Interior, deauthorizes the Blunt Reservoir feature. An unleased parcel is land not under lease purchased for the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features. The State of South Dakota may accept land and obligations as part of conveyances. The State of South Dakota may agree to accept the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features in their current condition, along with any liabilities arising from ownership. The Commission will act as the agent for the Secretary in administering purchase options for preferential leaseholders. The State of South Dakota may accept the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features with liabilities. Conveyances to the State are subject to reserved oil, gas, mineral rights, permits, leases, and conditions specified by the United States. The State of South Dakota may accept the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features with liabilities, subject to reservations by the United States and conditions specified in the Act of May 19, 1948. Preferential leaseholders have the option to purchase the lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission. The State of South Dakota may accept the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal features with liabilities, subject to reservations by the United States and conditions specified in the Act of May 19, 1948. Preferential leaseholders have the option to purchase the lease parcel from the Secretary or the Commission. The value of the parcel determined under paragraph (4) minus ten percent of that value. Preferential leaseholders have the option to purchase the lease parcel with 10 percent down and the remainder paid over 30 years at 3 percent interest. If the parcel is under $10,000, it must be purchased on a cash basis. The option to purchase must be exercised within 5 years of the enactment of the Act. Until then, leaseholders can continue to lease the parcel under the same terms. The value of a preferential lease parcel is determined by its fair market value for agricultural purposes, less 25 percent, in accordance with appraisal standards. Any disputes over the value are resolved as per federal regulations. The Secretary shall offer to convey a parcel to the State of South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks if a preferential leaseholder fails to purchase it. The land conveyed must be used for wildlife habitat mitigation. Proceeds from land sales will be deposited into the Treasury as miscellaneous funds for the State to establish a trust fund to pay county taxes. The Secretary will offer to convey nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. Land sales proceeds will establish a trust fund to pay county taxes. The South Dakota Commission of Schools and Public Lands may allow land exchanges for nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal with the concurrence of the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. Priority is given to exchanges with current lessees and adjoining landowners. The United States reserves a perpetual easement for water conveyance structures over the Pierre Canal feature in exchange for land. Upon conveyance of any parcel, the United States is released from liability for damages, except for acts of negligence committed before the conveyance date. (g) Requirements Concerning Conveyance of Lease Parcels. The Secretary must continue to lease each parcel under the current terms until conveyance. Parcel descriptions must be provided within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary, in consultation with the Commission, will provide the State with legal descriptions of lease parcels for conveyance. Archeological items from specific features will be transferred to the South Dakota State Historical Society. $750,000 is authorized for expenses related to implementing the Act. The Act authorizes $750,000 for expenses incurred, not to exceed 10 percent of each transaction conducted.
